interface.name: kde_output_device_v2
interface.description:
An output device describes a display device available to the compositor. output_device is similar to wl_output, but focuses on output configuration management.
A client can query all global output_device objects to enlist all available display devices, even those that may currently not be represented by the compositor as a wl_output.
The client sends configuration changes to the server through the outputconfiguration interface, and the server applies the configuration changes to the hardware and signals changes to the output devices accordingly.
This object is published as global during start up for every available display devices, or when one later becomes available, for example by being hotplugged via a physical connector.
Warning! The protocol described in this file is a desktop environment implementation detail. Regular clients must not use this protocol. Backward incompatible changes may be added without bumping the major version of the extension.

enum.name: subpixel
enum.description: This enumeration describes how the physical pixels on an output are laid out.

enum.name: transform
enum.description:
This describes the transform, that a compositor will apply to a surface to compensate for the rotation or mirroring of an output device.
The flipped values correspond to an initial flip around a vertical axis followed by rotation.
The purpose is mainly to allow clients to render accordingly and tell the compositor, so that for fullscreen surfaces, the compositor is still able to scan out directly client surfaces.

event.name: geometry
event.description: The geometry event describes geometric properties of the output. The event is sent when binding to the output object and whenever any of the properties change.

arg.name: x
arg.summary: x position within the global compositor space

arg.name: y
arg.summary: y position within the global compositor space

arg.name: physical_width
arg.summary: width in millimeters of the output

arg.name: physical_height
arg.summary: height in millimeters of the output

arg.name: transform
arg.summary: transform that maps framebuffer to output

event.name: current_mode
event.description: This event describes the mode currently in use for this head. It is only sent if the output is enabled.

event.name: mode

description.summary: advertise available output modes and current one

event.description:
The mode event describes an available mode for the output.
When the client binds to the output_device object, the server sends this event once for every available mode the output_device can be operated by.
There will always be at least one event sent out on initial binding, which represents the current mode.
Later if an output changes, its mode event is sent again for the eventual added modes and lastly the current mode. In other words, the current mode is always represented by the latest event sent with the current flag set.
The size of a mode is given in physical hardware units of the output device. This is not necessarily the same as the output size in the global compositor space. For instance, the output may be scaled, as described in kde_output_device_v2.scale, or transformed, as described in kde_output_device_v2.transform.

event.name: done
event.description: This event is sent after all other properties have been sent on binding to the output object as well as after any other output property change have been applied later on. This allows to see changes to the output properties as atomic, even if multiple events successively announce them.

event.name: scale
event.description:
This event contains scaling geometry information that is not in the geometry event. It may be sent after binding the output object or if the output scale changes later. If it is not sent, the client should assume a scale of 1.
A scale larger than 1 means that the compositor will automatically scale surface buffers by this amount when rendering. This is used for high resolution displays where applications rendering at the native resolution would be too small to be legible.
It is intended that scaling aware clients track the current output of a surface, and if it is on a scaled output it should use wl_surface.set_buffer_scale with the scale of the output. That way the compositor can avoid scaling the surface, and the client can supply a higher detail image.

event.name: edid

description.summary: advertise EDID data for the output

event.description:
The edid event encapsulates the EDID data for the outputdevice.
The event is sent when binding to the output object. The EDID data may be empty, in which case this event is sent anyway. If the EDID information is empty, you can fall back to the name et al. properties of the outputdevice.

event.name: enabled
event.description: The enabled event notifies whether this output is currently enabled and used for displaying content by the server. The event is sent when binding to the output object and whenever later on an output changes its state by becoming enabled or disabled.

event.name: uuid

description.summary: A unique id for this outputdevice

event.description: The uuid can be used to identify the output. It's controlled by the server entirely. The server should make sure the uuid is persistent across restarts. An empty uuid is considered invalid.

event.name: serial_number
event.description: Serial ID of the monitor, sent on startup before the first done event.

event.name: eisa_id
event.description: EISA ID of the monitor, sent on startup before the first done event.

enum.name: capability
enum.description: Describes what capabilities this device has.

entry.name: overscan
entry.summary: if this output_device can use overscan

entry.name: vrr
entry.summary: if this outputdevice supports variable refresh rate

entry.name: rgb_range
entry.summary: if setting the rgb range is possible

entry.name: high_dynamic_range
entry.summary: if this outputdevice supports high dynamic range

entry.name: wide_color_gamut
entry.summary: if this outputdevice supports a wide color gamut

entry.name: icc_profile
entry.summary: if this outputdevice supports icc profiles

entry.name: brightness
entry.summary: if this outputdevice supports the brightness setting

event.name: capabilities
event.description: What capabilities this device has, sent on startup before the first done event.

event.name: overscan
event.description: Overscan value of the monitor in percent, sent on startup before the first done event.

arg.name: overscan
arg.summary: amount of overscan of the monitor

enum.name: vrr_policy
enum.description: Describes when the compositor may employ variable refresh rate

event.name: vrr_policy
event.description: What policy the compositor will employ regarding its use of variable refresh rate.

enum.name: rgb_range
enum.description: Whether full or limited color range should be used

event.name: rgb_range
event.description: What rgb range the compositor is using for this output

event.name: name
event.description: Name of the output, it's useful to cross-reference to an zxdg_output_v1 and ultimately QScreen

event.name: high_dynamic_range
event.description: Whether or not high dynamic range is enabled for this output

event.name: sdr_brightness

description.summary: the brightness of sdr if hdr is enabled

event.description: If high dynamic range is used, this value defines the brightness in nits for content that's in standard dynamic range format. Note that while the value is in nits, that doesn't necessarily translate to the same brightness on the screen.

event.name: wide_color_gamut
event.description: Whether or not the use of a wide color gamut is enabled for this output

description.summary: describes when auto rotate should be used
describes when auto rotate is used
describes when auto rotate is used
metadata about the screen's brightness limits
overrides for the screen's brightness limits

arg.name: max_peak_brightness
arg.summary: -1 for no override, positive values are the brightness in nits

arg.name: max_average_brightness
arg.summary: -1 for no override, positive values are the brightness in nits

arg.name: min_brightness
arg.summary: -1 for no override, positive values are the brightness in 0.0001 nits

event.name: sdr_gamut_wideness

description.summary: describes which gamut is assumed for sRGB applications

event.description: This can be used to provide the colors users assume sRGB applications should have based on the default experience on many modern sRGB screens.

arg.name: gamut_wideness
arg.summary: 0 means rec.709 primaries, 10000 means native primaries

description.summary: which source the compositor should use for the color profile on an output
describes which source the compositor uses for the color profile on an output

event.name: brightness
event.description: This is the brightness modifier of the output. It doesn't specify any absolute values, but is merely a multiplier on top of other brightness values, like sdr_brightness and brightness_metadata. 0 is the minimum brightness (not completely dark) and 10000 is the maximum brightness. This is currently only supported / meaningful while HDR is active.

enum.name: color_power_tradeoff
enum.description: The compositor can do a lot of things that trade between performance, power and color accuracy. This setting describes a high level preference from the user about in which direction that tradeoff should be made.

event.name: dimming
event.description: This is the dimming multiplier of the output. This is similar to the brightness setting, except it's meant to be a temporary setting only, not persistent and may be implemented differently depending on the display. 0 is the minimum dimming factor (not completely dark) and 10000 means the output is not dimmed.

interface.name: kde_output_device_mode_v2
interface.description:
This object describes an output mode.
Some heads don't support output modes, in which case modes won't be advertised.
Properties sent via this interface are applied atomically via the kde_output_device.done event. No guarantees are made regarding the order in which properties are sent.

event.name: size
event.description: This event describes the mode size. The size is given in physical hardware units of the output device. This is not necessarily the same as the output size in the global compositor space. For instance, the output may be scaled or transformed.

arg.name: width
arg.summary: width of the mode in hardware units

arg.name: height
arg.summary: height of the mode in hardware units

event.name: refresh
event.description: This event describes the mode's fixed vertical refresh rate. It is only sent if the mode has a fixed refresh rate.

event.name: preferred
event.description: This event advertises this mode as preferred.

event.name: removed
event.description: The compositor will destroy the object immediately after sending this event, so it will become invalid and the client should release any resources associated with it.
